poem:
Corrections

In the hush of marble halls,  
fact bends to grace,  
as the wall, not sky, holds judgment.  
Cardinals shuffle, hats in hand,  
like actors on their fourth take.  
Meanwhile, India stands corrected,  
its diplomat's title gently mended.  
Truth, a fresco upon a ceiling,  
or a name worn like a coat.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. Also, there will be four, not two, rounds of voting a day. • Vikram Misri is India’s foreign secretary, not the foreign minister as an article said (Flare-ups in the region are not new, but restraint is crumbling". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
